H0.text: Radio waves are the type of electromagnetic radiation whose strong source causes the breakdown of ozone into oxygen in the ozone layer, as described by the electromagnetic absorption spectrum of ozone.

H1.text: Microwaves are the strong source of electromagnetic radiation that causes the breakdown of ozone into oxygen in the ozone layer.

H2.text: Infrared light is the type of electromagnetic radiation that, when ozone is exposed to a strong source of it, causes the breakdown of ozone into oxygen in the ozone layer.

H3.text: Ultraviolet light is the type of electromagnetic radiation that, when ozone is exposed to a strong source, causes the breakdown of ozone into oxygen, producing oxygen in the ozone layer.

A4.text: the shorter bands of UVC, as well as even more-energetic UV radiation produced by the Sun, are absorbed by oxygen and generate the ozone in the ozone layer when single oxygen atoms produced by UV photolysis of dioxygen react with more dioxygen.

A5.text: The ozone layer is especially important in blocking most UVB and the remaining part of UVC not already blocked by ordinary oxygen in air.

A6.text: When ultraviolet light hits ozone it splits into a molecule of O2 and an individual atom of oxygen.

A7.text: Ozone is removed when an oxygen atom and an ozone molecule 'recombine' to form two oxygen molecules, i.e. O + O3 → 2O2.

A8.text: Ozone can be destroyed by a number of free radical catalysts; the most important are the hydroxyl radical (OH·), nitric oxide radical (NO·), chlorine radical (Cl·) and bromine radical (Br·).

A9.text: O3 + hν → O2 + O(^1D) λ <320 nm

A10.text: The absorption of radiation in the atmosphere would cause photodissociation of nitrogen, generating nitric oxide that would act as a catalyst to destroy ozone.

A11.text: A closely related subdiscipline is atmospheric photochemistry, which quantifies the rate that molecules are split apart by sunlight, determines the resulting products, and obtains thermodynamic data such as Henry's law coefficients.

A12.text: Ozone is transparent to most UV-A, so most of this longer-wavelength UV radiation reaches the surface, and it constitutes most of the UV reaching the Earth.
